claim: If you prick your finger on a spindle, you will fall asleep.

supporting.text: In the fairy tale 'Sleeping Beauty,' pricking a finger on a spindle causes the protagonist to fall into a deep sleep.

attacks.text: In the fairy tale 'Sleeping Beauty,' pricking a finger on a spindle causes the protagonist to fall into a deep sleep.
Fairy tales are fictional and do not reflect real-world causality.
While fairy tales are fictional, they often incorporate symbolic or exaggerated versions of real-world phenomena.
No scientific evidence supports the claim that pricking a finger on a spindle induces sleep.
Historical accounts mention sleep-inducing substances applied to spindles or needles, suggesting a possible basis for the tale.
The claim is culturally specific and not universally recognized outside the context of 'Sleeping Beauty.'

supporting.text: Medically, pricking a finger on a spindle does not induce sleep; it may cause minor pain or infection if not treated properly.

attacks.text: Medically, pricking a finger on a spindle does not induce sleep; it may cause minor pain or infection if not treated properly.

Certain toxins or sedatives applied to a spindle could theoretically induce sleep if introduced into the bloodstream via a prick.
Such scenarios are highly speculative and lack documented evidence in medical literature.
